title: The Countess of Wessex cuts an elegant figure as she visits Brainwave Therapy Centre
text:
The Countess of Wessex appeared effortlessly stylish as she celebrated the Brainwave Therapy Centre's tenth anniversary in Cheshire today.

Sophie Wessex, 54, looked upbeat as she met with children and parents at the Cheshire establishment and acknowledged the vital work carried out by the charity.

The royal, who shares two children with Prince Edward, 55, appeared in high spirits as she made her way through the centre while donning a black floral dress layered underneath a slick black blazer.

The Countess of Wessex, 54, looked stylish in a black floral dress layered underneath a slick black blazer as she visited the Brainwave Therapy Centre in Cheshire on Wednesday

Sophie appeared in high spirits as she met with children and parents at the Cheshire establishment

She teamed her autumnal look with a stylish beige clutch bag by her side as she walked through the charity's building.

Sophie accessorised her look with a pair of stylish gold hooped earrings and a single black hair clip placed at the back of her hair.

Letting her blonde locks rest gently against her shoulders, the royal completed her look with a touch of make-up to accentuate her naturally glowing features.

During the day, Sophie spoke with staff at the charity and visited the multi-sensory room to witness first-hand how the charity, which provides educational and physical therapies to children with disabilities, was helping children.

Later during the day the countess visited Tarporley War Memorial Hospital to speak with veterans in its care.

The royal, who teamed her autumnal look with a stlyish beige clutch bag by her side, acknowledged the vital work carried out by the charity

She later visited the Tarporley War Memorial Hospital to speak with veterans in its care

The hospital, which celebrated its 100th birthday this year, is one of a few remaining centres in the UK that specialises in inpatient and intermediate care of the elderly.

Sophie's appearance comes less than a month after she visited Musgrove Park Hospital at the Somerset hospital to unveil the establishment's new MRI scanner.

The busy Countess recently returned from a visit to Nairobi focused on gender equality and the prevention of sexual violence.

During her visit she met with refugees who are part of the RefuSHE girls empowerment programme, many from Somalia, South Sudan and other countries facing conflict.

As part of the programme the girls are given the opportunity to learn skills that can be used to make an income in addition to shelter, education and legal advocacy support.
